item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: 5 Principles for Iraq
item.description: There are many questions that need answering before the U.S. considers intervening.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

item.title: Opinion: The U.S. Military’s Campaign Against Media Freedom
item.description: I saw firsthand how the United States military rationed what the American public knew about its operations in Iraq.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By CHELSEA MANNING
item.media:description: A supporter of Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki protested in Baghdad on March 26, 2010, with a poster depicting inked fingers being hanged and alleging voter fraud in Iraq’s general election.

item.title: Beleaguered Iraqis Court Iranian Mastermind of the Shiites Who Fought the U.S.
item.description: Iraq may see the possibility of significant aid from Iran as a means of pressuring the United States to come to Iraq’s defense with aid of its own.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT, MARK MAZZETTI and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Changing Maps in the Mideast
item.description: The facts on the ground are shredding the official maps of Iraq and the region.
item.dc:creator: By ROSS DOUTHAT

item.title: Afghans Vote With Guarded Optimism, Looking Ahead to U.S. Withdrawal
item.description: As voters chose Saturday between an ex-finance minister and an opposition politician, the Taliban appeared not to have launched any major attacks, at least in urban areas.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Afghan women lined up to vote at a polling station in Herat on Saturday.

item.title: Iraq Rebels Stall North of Baghdad as Residents Brace for a Siege
item.description: An insurgent juggernaut that captured Iraq’s second-largest city and raced nearly 200 miles south in three days stalled on Saturday, leaving residents in Baghdad bracing for a siege that so far has not happened.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Thousands of volunteers have joined the Iraqi Army to combat the predominantly Sunni militants after Iraq’s most senior Shiite cleric urged followers to take up arms.

item.title: Separatists Down Military Transport Jet, Killing 49 in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: The death toll Saturday was the largest in a single incident for the Ukrainian military since the unrest began in the country’s east.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: An armed pro-Russian separatist gathered ammunition at the site of the crash in Luhansk on Saturday.

item.title: From Untended Farmland, Reserve Tries to Recreate Wilderness From Long Ago
item.description: A reserve in western Spain is at the forefront of Europe’s “rewilding” effort, which seeks to restore species and ecosystems that vanished centuries ago.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: An abandoned farm near La Alamedilla. Rewilders say introducing wildlife, especially large herbivores, will prevent the land from becoming overgrown, which could hurt biodiversity.

item.title: Military Analysis: U.S. Airstrikes Could Help in Reversing Insurgent Offensive, Experts Say
item.description: Advisers and better intelligence could improve United States air power in an effort to assist the Nuri Kamal al-Maliki government.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and HELENE COOPER

item.title: World Briefing: Tunisia: Deal Paves Way for Elections
item.description: Tunisian politicians announced Friday that they had resolved a longstanding dispute and had agreed to hold parliamentary elections before the country’s presidential vote.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Myanmar: Opposition Is Dealt a Blow
item.description: A parliamentary committee has voted against changing a clause in Myanmar’s Constitution that bars the opposition leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, left, from becoming president.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Greece: Huge Heroin Shipment Seized
item.description: Greek officials said Friday that a record 1.1 tons of heroin were seized and 11 people arrested east of Athens in a joint operation with the United States Drug Enforcement Administration.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Malaysia: Jet Insurance Payments Begin
item.description: Malaysia Airlines has begun giving out $50,000 in advance insurance payments to families of people aboard the missing Flight 370, but many Chinese relatives have indicated that they will reject the money.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Thailand: Nationwide Curfew Lifted
item.description: Thailand’s military government announced Friday that it had fully lifted a nationwide curfew it imposed after seizing power last month.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Reprisal Killings Reported in Iraq’s Militant-Held Areas
item.description: Sunni militants in Iraq are rounding up former government workers, allowing some to repent and live while executing others, residents and a United Nations official said.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Navi Pillay, the United Nations human rights chief, said the number of recent killings in Iraq “may run into the hundreds.”

item.title: Mexico 1, Cameroon 0: World Cup 2014: Mexico Secures Win Against Cameroon
item.description: Neither the relentless rain nor the contentious officiating rattled the Mexican players, who dismantled Cameroon in a performance that belied the final scoreline.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW KEH
item.media:description: Cameroon’s Samuel Eto’o, right, challenging Hector Moreno during Mexico’s 1-0 victory Friday before an announced crowd of 39,216 at Estadio das Dunas.

item.title: Seeing Their Gains at Risk, Shiites Flock to Join Militias
item.description: Skills honed on behalf of President Bashar al-Assad will be used for militia groups battling the Sunnis who are driving toward Baghdad.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: An Iraqi Shiite cleaned weapons on Friday as he prepared to defend his Sadr City district in Baghdad in the event of an attack by Sunni militants.

item.title: Veterans Watch as Gains Their Friends Died for Are Erased by Insurgents
item.description: Hundreds of Americans lost their lives battling for control of parts of Iraq that are falling to militants with breathtaking speed.
item.dc:creator: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr.
item.media:credit: Eros Hoagland for The New York Times
item.media:description: The First Battalion, 327th Infantry Regiment safeguarded Baiji Oil Refinery from 2007 through 2008. Insurgents from Mosul are now attempting to overtake it.

item.title: Taliban Run Into Trouble on Battlefield, but Money Flows Just the Same
item.description: Rising revenues from opium trafficking and other such ventures could increase the longevity of the insurgency, Afghan and Western officials say.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: A money market in Afghanistan. The Taliban are believed to have earned record revenues last year, with a bumper opium harvest in Afghanistan helping pad insurgent coffers.

item.title: Iraqi Shiite Cleric Issues Call to Arms
item.description: The specter of sectarian war and partition of Iraq grew as Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani told his followers to take up arms against an insurgent army of marauding Sunni militants.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN, SUADAD AL-SALHY and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Ayman Oghanna for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shiite volunteers during a tribal meeting in northern Baghdad.

item.title: No Ceremony for Bowe Bergdahl Upon Return to U.S. Soil
item.description: Exactly 1,809 days after he was captured, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl returned to a homecoming void of any relatives and dampened by a controversy over his capture and release.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MANNY FERNANDEZ and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:credit: Erin Trieb for The New York Times
item.media:description: Media awaited the arrival of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl Brooke Army Medical Center in San Antonio.

item.title: Iraq’s Factions and Their Goals
item.description: The goals of of the three main groups in Iraq — Sunni, Shiite and Kurdish — as the country threatens to split apart along sectarian lines.

item.title: Mayor of Venice Resigns Amid Corruption Scandal
item.description: Mayor Giorgio Orsoni had been arrested last week and charged with receiving illegal campaign donations believed to be linked to a project intended to save Venice from flooding.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Russia Sent Tanks to Separatists in Ukraine, U.S. Says
item.description: After the State Department said that Russia had sent weapons to rebels in Ukraine, separatists using antiaircraft and heavy machine guns fired on a military transport plane in Luhansk, the Ukrainian Defense Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers returning from combat on Friday after pushing back separatist fighters around the port city of Mariupol in the Donetsk region.

item.title: Israeli Teenagers Said to Be Kidnapped in West Bank
item.description: Initial reports said the three teenagers, one with American citizenship, were last heard from on Thursday on their way to a hitchhiking area south of Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
